intro: Sida montana f. pseudorhombifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaf sida, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant typically grows as an annual herb with hairy, lanceolate leaves that are often mistaken for those of other species. Its small, yellowish-white flowers are clustered in dense inflorescences, and it produces capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. This plant is adapted to arid environments and is often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides.
